TopicTitle: hiya, new here. But just wondering has anyone gotten this far up?

Articles.Content:
yeah a couple of times

once you perfect your rockets to go up and far you will get alot further

another fun thing to do is orbit the planet
I've gotten to around 25K Km before I gave up. Funny, though, I didn't know about hitting 'T' to keep the SAS running, so I was holding 'F' the entire hour and 45 minutes.

I've gotten to around 25K Km before I gave up. Funny, though, I didn't know about hitting 'T' to keep the SAS running, so I was holding 'F' the entire hour and 45 minutes.

lol, I did the same thing before learning about 'T'.

lol, I did the same thing before learning about 'T'.

Me too, except the longest mission I've done is 50 minutes and that was only up to 10 000 Km

I've gotten to around 25K Km before I gave up. Funny, though, I didn't know about hitting 'T' to keep the SAS running, so I was holding 'F' the entire hour and 45 minutes.

Oh dammit, I have always been holding down F...

I had a rocket that was cruising at 2000m/s after escaping the Kerballian gravity. I then proceeded to take a nap. Which turned into an 8 hour sleep (for future reference, naps at 2am have a tendency to become 8 hour sleeps). When I woke up, my rocket was at 66894K and counting, T +09:34:23.
I once got an exit velocity of 3000 m/s, and it kept going at that speed for the next three hours.
Got to 75000 K when I left it over night.

My best was just over 12 hours.

Speed was 24,567 m/s, distance was just over 1.1 Million km..

I noticed it is able to go into the billions.. I am tempted to load this into one of my other computers and let it fly for a month.

Going to try to break my previous best.

Current speed: 36,636 m/s, distance: 220,000 km, time: 18 min 45 sec

Going to let it run for a while.
I'm all about circular orbits. I've gotten into a circular orbit at 10,000 kilometers. At that height the orbital period is like 30 hours or something.

I'm all about circular orbits. I've gotten into a circular orbit at 10,000 kilometers. At that height the orbital period is like 30 hours or something.

My younger brother accidentally got an orbit of 50+ hours. No, we did not sit there and let it run, we used a calculator. The orbit was also ridiculously elliptical, perigee was only at 50,000ish, but apogee was in the hundreds of millions of meters. Should have taken a screen shot, but didn't think to.
